item.title: The magic 8-bit drums
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
So. There’s the easy way, and then the not easy way.

The easy way is to load up samples and apply a bit crusher. Auxy has no such animal, GarageBand and other apps do. GB actually has a bit crusher directly available on some of the drum kits. It would get you close.

Stuff like this though was/is primarily done on a tracker. When you think about the sound architecture of a Gameboy or Nintendo, you’re talking (without expansion ROM chips like Konami and junk used) max five channels, including noise.

Looking at Nintendo, you had two square Wave channels with PWM, a triangle and noise. Can’t recall if sine was there, actually I think not and then that means there’s actually four channels.

A triangle wave melody is usually the bass line / kick, depending on modulation. Squares are usually your leads and noise is snare / hats (depending on volume and modulation).

A good free way to play with this is Famitracker, Windows only. You could also check out Sunvox though it’s not the same under the hood. That’s at least cross platform.

That’s about all I can say on this. 8bit / chip time is one genre I could never wrap my head around.
